statement.tex: %text Find the coordinates of the point where the line through the points $A(3,4,1)$ and $B(5,1,6)$ cross the XY-plane. %

step.context: %text What is the equation of the line through the points $(3,4,1)$ and $(5,1,6)$? %
step.reason: %text Equation of a line joining any two points $(x_1, y_1,z_1)$ and $(x_2,y_2,z_2)$ is given by % \qquad\dfrac{x-x_1}{x_2-x_1}=\dfrac{y-y_1}{y_2-y_1} =\dfrac{z-z_1}{z_2-z_1}. \\ %text Therefore for the given points $(3,4,1)$ and $(5,1,6)$, we have, % \begin{align} &\dfrac{x-3}{5-3}=\dfrac{y-4}{1-4}=\dfrac{z-1}{6-1} \\ \implies&\dfrac{x-3}{2}=\dfrac{y-4}{-3}=\dfrac{z-1}{5} \end{align}

step.context: %text What are the correct equations for the $x$-$y$, $y$-$z$ and $z$-$x$ planes? %
step.reason: %text The $x$-$y$ plane is simply all points that have their $z$ coordinate as zero. Therefore the equation of the $x$-$y$ plane is $z=0$. Similarly for the $y$-$z$ and $z$-$x$ planes. %

step.context: %text What is the point of intersection of the $x$-$y$ plane and line $\dfrac{x-3}{2}=\dfrac{y-4}{-3}=\dfrac{z-1}{5}$? %
step.reason:
%text To find the point of intersection, substitute the equation of the plane $z=0$ into the equation of the line and solve. %
\begin{align} &\dfrac{x-3}{2}=\dfrac{y-4}{-3}=\dfrac{0-1}{5} \\ \implies &\dfrac{x-3}{2}=\dfrac{y-4}{-3}=\dfrac{-1}{5} \\ \implies &x=-\dfrac{2}{5}+3=\dfrac{13}{5} \\ \implies &y=\dfrac{3}{5}+4=\dfrac{23}{5} \end{align} \\ %text Point if intersection is $\left(\dfrac{13}{5}, \dfrac{23}{5}, 0\right)$ %
